mods.abstract: Cooper primarily discusses African-American owned businesses in South Baton Rouge in the 1940s-1960s, describing in detail the locations of business, churches, funeral homes and well-known landmarks in the neighborhood. He talks about gravel roads, changing street names, former locations of still-operating business and the demolition of buildings. He discusses the decline of black-owned businesses in South Baton Rouge and his frustration over black-on-black crime. He describes segregated medical care at Baton Rouge General Hospital and an ambulance service (operated by his employer, Desselle Funeral Home) that took patients to and from Charity Hospital in New Orleans. He also discusses funeral homes in Baton Rouge, especially those for African Americans.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.0699. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Rudolph Henry and Michael Goods.

Herman Cooper was born in Baton Rouge, La., to [Frank?] Cooper and Cora Johnson Cooper. He had an older brother, James, and a younger brother, Leander. At age sixteen, he took a job at Capital Funeral Home and later briefly worked for People's Funeral Home. He left in 1948 to work for the newly established Desselle Funeral Home, where he stayed for the remainder of his career. Cooper passed away in 2011 at age eighty-three.
